--- title: Selection lang: en subtitle: Pandas Introduction author: Jan Kirenz execute: eval: true echo: true highlight-style: github format: revealjs: toc: true toc-depth: 1 embed-resources: false theme: [dark, ../custom.scss] incremental: true transition: slide background-transition: fade transition-speed: slow code-copy: true code-line-numbers: true smaller: false scrollable: true slide-number: c preview-links: auto chalkboard: buttons: false #logo: images/logo.png footer: Jan Kirenz --- # Setup ::: {#8ed469b2 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.python .cell-code} import pandas as pd ``` ::: ::: {#5fef461a .cell execution_count=2} ``` {.python .cell-code code-line-numbers="|1|2|3|4|5|"} df = pd.DataFrame({ 'name': ["Tom", "Lisa", "Peter"], 'height': [1.68, 1.93, 1.72], 'weight': [48.4, 89.8, 84.2], 'id': [1, 2, 3], 'city': ['Stuttgart', 'Stuttgart', 'Berlin'] }) df['bmi'] = round(df['weight'] / (df['height'] * df['height']), 2) df["name"] = df["name"].astype("category") df['id'] = df['id'].astype(str) ``` ::: # Getting Columns # Getting columns with [[]] - Selecting a single column with `[[]]`: - Select the column `city` and save it as a new Pandas dataframe `df_city` . . . ::: {#33d1b0de .cell execution_count=3} ``` {.python .cell-code} df_city = df[["city"]] ``` ::: . . . ::: {#ecee7b33 .cell output-location='fragment' execution_count=4} ``` {.python .cell-code} df_city ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=4} ```{=html}
city
0 Stuttgart
1 Stuttgart
2 Berlin
``` ::: ::: # Selecting rows ## Selecting rows with [] - Selecting via `[]` slices the rows (endpoint is not included) and includes all columns: ::: {#3cf863d2 .cell output-location='fragment' execution_count=5} ``` {.python .cell-code} df[0:2] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=5} ```{=html}
name height weight id city bmi
0 Tom 1.68 48.4 1 Stuttgart 17.15
1 Lisa 1.93 89.8 2 Stuttgart 24.11
``` ::: ::: # Location: loc ## Location - The `.loc` (location) attribute is the primary access method. - For getting only the first row: . . . ::: {#55ef23fb .cell output-location='fragment' execution_count=6} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.loc[[0]] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=6} ```{=html}
name height weight id city bmi
0 Tom 1.68 48.4 1 Stuttgart 17.15
``` ::: ::: ## Selecting on a multi-axis by label - Only select location at row 0 for column "name" . . . ::: {#abd9554d .cell output-location='fragment' execution_count=7} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.loc[0, 'name'] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=7} ``` 'Tom' ``` ::: ::: ## Selecting on a multi-axis by label - Select row 2 to 4 for column "name" (when using .loc endpoints are included) . . . ::: {#5fadcd8c .cell output-location='fragment' execution_count=8} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.loc[2:4, 'name'] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=8} ``` 2 Peter Name: name, dtype: category Categories (3, object): ['Lisa', 'Peter', 'Tom'] ``` ::: ::: ## Selecting on a multi-axis by label - Select row 2 to 4 for columns "name" and "height" (when using .loc endpoints are included) . . . ::: {#d4245655 .cell output-location='fragment' execution_count=9} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.loc[2:4, ['name', 'height']] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=9} ```{=html}
name height
2 Peter 1.72
``` ::: ::: ## Selecting on a multi-axis by label - Select all rows for name and height . . . ::: {#5544ccda .cell output-location='fragment' execution_count=10} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.loc[:, ["name", "height"]] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=10} ```{=html}
name height
0 Tom 1.68
1 Lisa 1.93
2 Peter 1.72
``` ::: ::: ## Getting a scalar value ::: {#996ba34f .cell execution_count=11} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.loc[[0], "height"] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=11} ``` 0 1.68 Name: height, dtype: float64 ``` ::: ::: # Integer based indexing: .iloc ## Integer based indexing .iloc {.smaller} - Pandas provides a suite of methods in order to get purely integer based indexing. - Here, the `.iloc` attribute is the primary access method. . . . ::: {#301ab22a .cell output-location='fragment' execution_count=12} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.iloc[0] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=12} ``` name Tom height 1.68 weight 48.4 id 1 city Stuttgart bmi 17.15 Name: 0, dtype: object ``` ::: ::: ## By integer slices - *When using `.iloc`, endpoints are not included.* . . . ::: {#ad8d8578 .cell output-location='fragment' execution_count=13} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.iloc[0:2, 0:2] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=13} ```{=html}
name height
0 Tom 1.68
1 Lisa 1.93
``` ::: ::: ## By lists of integer position locations ::: {#c4a06953 .cell output-location='fragment' execution_count=14} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.iloc[[0, 2], [0, 1]] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=14} ```{=html}
name height
0 Tom 1.68
2 Peter 1.72
``` ::: ::: ## For slicing rows explicitly ::: {#3b92350e .cell output-location='fragment' execution_count=15} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.iloc[1:3, :] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=15} ```{=html}
name height weight id city bmi
1 Lisa 1.93 89.8 2 Stuttgart 24.11
2 Peter 1.72 84.2 3 Berlin 28.46
``` ::: ::: ## For slicing columns explicitly ::: {#103d4e81 .cell output-location='fragment' execution_count=16} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.iloc[:, 1:3] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=16} ```{=html}
height weight
0 1.68 48.4
1 1.93 89.8
2 1.72 84.2
``` ::: ::: ## For getting a value explicitly ::: {#1bc1818d .cell execution_count=17} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.iloc[0, 0] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=17} ``` 'Tom' ``` ::: :::
